1325804298245189634.content:
This is a short tutorial on how the #decarbnow map works. We can add markers to the map through Twitter by just adding the URL of the map to any tweet. Here, we see the city of Ürümqi in the N-W of China. The pin appears in the middle of the screen.
https://t.co/duEialYmqp

1325804300480737280.content:
Several layers are available on the map. e.g. we can see the average NO2 pollution cloud of 2007 over Ürümqi. NO2 serves as a proxy for anthrophonic #CO2 emissions; sources are easier to trace than CO2 sources as NO2 is mostly absent in nature. #hide
https://t.co/FXBXljAUN1

1325804302716301312.content:
NO2 is created by burning #fossilfuels; the same process that creates CO2. It dissolves from the atmosphere hours after its release. The active layer (2011 summer time averages) is calculated from #NASA OMI satellite data. #hide
https://t.co/7EMpz0hWmO

1325804304880513024.content:
The main sources of NO2 are traffic & energy production. In 2011, the coal power plant cluster in the N-E of the city hasn't been build yet (red dots). Btw, with #hide we can hide the tweet if we don't want to add it to the map.
https://t.co/mp7uuh6PvH

1301490635850108928.content: New temperature records were set in 2020. 20 June, the Siberian town of Verkhoyansk located at 67.55°N above the Arctic circle experienced 38°C (100.4°F) for the first time. For 10 days, maximum temperatures in June exceeded 30°C. https://t.co/Axb2OWgURd

1301490802317819904.content: On the Svalbard archipelago, even further North, at 78°N, a new temperature measurement crushed a 41-year-old record, with 21.7°C (71°F) recorded in Longyearbyen town 25 July. https://t.co/LZdhaOhwHr

1301491094660710400.content: Going further North, Eureka station in Nunavut reported 21.9°C (71.4°F) on 11 August. The heatwave was accompanied by huge wildfires in Russia, a very low sea ice extent, and the collapse of one of the last fully intact Canadian ice shelves. 👇 https://t.co/Z2wPjZPR8T

1301491334868594688.content: 31 July, 81 km2 (30 mi2) of the Milne ice shelf broke off, reducing it by 43%. The consequences: the loss of a rare ecosystem, the potential acceleration of glaciers into the ocean, and the formation of new drifting ice islands resulting from the calving. https://t.co/Drf3sFiMAp

1301491547154845697.content: 17 August, a flood occurred from a small marginal lake at the western margin of the Langjökull, #Iceland´s second largest ice cap. The lake has been forming over the past 20 years due to the steady retreat of the glacier. https://t.co/EvuaTeyO7i

1301491804601233408.content: Temperatures in the European Alps have increased by 2°C during the 20th Century. A sustained heatwave was recorded through July and beginning of August. 40.4°C was recorded at the beginning of July in Ayze, a small town in the Mont Blanc massif, ... https://t.co/68VJXYxZXI

1301491990408953856.content: ... while in early August 5°C was measured at 4000m altitude above Courmayeur, on the Italian side of Mont Blanc. https://t.co/r3kjavrAzZ

1301492552189784064.content: The Turtmann Glacier in the Valais Alps split, losing 300k m3 in a collapse on 6 August. D. Farinotti @ETH_en: “The glacier retreat that we observe in the Alps does not only affect our landscapes, but also our water resources and parts of our economy." https://t.co/eXIe7BZUgV

1301492774538276865.content: Planpincieux glacier in Italy, located in the Mont Blanc massif, Aosta Valley, above Cormayeur, has been on the brink of collapse for over 2 years. More than 500 000 m3 of ice were gradually peeling off from the main body of the glacier. https://t.co/HKVdNfxrB9

1300524409808134145.content: @CopernicusEU's #Sentinel3 image shows the drying of the Aral Sea. Climate change leads to short, hot summers and long, cold winters, and a decrease in precipitations. 1276062971089870850.content: So, we want to show off with #decarbnow a bit. We added NO2 layers as a proxy for #CO2 emissions caused by humans. Sources are easier to trace than CO2 sources as NO2 is mostly absent in nature and dissolves from the atmosphere hours after release. #hide https://t.co/U5fezDho2v

1276063123552731136.content:
The active layer, 2019 summer time averages, is calculated from #NASA OMI satellite data. Cities (green dots) and coal plants (red dots) map NO2 #pollution quite accurately, as seen here in the US ... #hide 
https://t.co/wEBYbvATEH

1276063259255341056.content:
... or in India. NO2 is created by burning #fossilfuels; the same process that creates CO2. The main sources of NO2 are traffic and energy production from e.g. #coal or #oil. #hide
https://t.co/ufK4Z0Thd0

1276063260643602432.content:
Also Eastern Asia experiences high NO2 levels in comparison to other parts of the world. #hide
https://t.co/DYtbhhveAQ

1276063442617729025.content:
Especially in highly industrialised areas like Korea and Japan #NO2 levels are high. We also calculated monthly NO2 averages from high resolution @ESA_EO @CopernicusEU @Sentinel5p data; this layers shows levels from March 2020. #hide
